prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe 6 lines within three basebands and to keep one baseband for continuum at 214.5Ghz. The continuum baseband will be used to estimate masses for the detected protostellar or prestellar cores.
The estimated continuum sensitivity (sigma = 320?Jy/beam) for a 3-sigma detection is 0.96mJy/beam (34.2mK), which is the 215GHz continuum flux expected for a 0.3 Msun core at 1.7kpc (with kappa=0.01 cm2 g-1 and T=20K).
We expect minimum linewidths of ~0.7km/s for 13CS and N2D+ lines (Tan et al. 2013) and thus need a 13CS-N2D+ spectral window resolution of 0.158km/s.
We spectrally averaged outflows and infalls lines that we anticipate to be broader to save up datarate.

We propose to observe the 29 MDCs of NGC 6334 with ALMA. We aim to reach a 0.8" synthetized beam corresponding to 1500 AU at the 1.7kpc distance of NGC 6334. Previous interferometric studies of massive dense cores in Cygnus-X (Bontemps et al. 2010) or fragmentation in I(N) (Hunter et al. 2014) found that high-mass protostars in such cores (at a resolution of 1700 AU and 650 AU respectively) have deconvolved sizes on the order of 1000-2500 AU and mean separation of ~4000 AU.
We here ask for 7-pointing mosaics on 21 sources (out of 29) to image 30"x30" which should cover the full size of outflows traced by CO(2-1), SiO(5-4) and SO(56-45) (at most a few 0.1pc, see Fig.3-Center). TP observations are necessary to make sense of DCO+ and DCN line emissions, expected to arise from large-scale (up to 40") inflowing streams (see Fig.3-Right).
A second SG will investigate the complementary sample of 8 sources which are clustered at less than 30". We propose mosaics of 14, 23 and 14-pointings to spare redundant pointings.

We plan to assess the turbulence of the fragments using both 13CS and N2D+, 13CS being more suited for protostellar MDCs and N2D+ for starless MDCs. While 13 CS has been found to be an excellent tracer of high-mass Iprotostellar cores (Fechtenbaum et al. in prep.), it can be depleted in cold environment where N2D+ is enhanced and becomes a better tracer (Tan et al. 2013).
On one hand, Tan et al. (2013) uses ALMA Cycle 0 observations of prestellar dense cores embedded in IRDCS and detected N2D+ but not 13CS lines. Their intermediate-mass pre-stellar does display N2D+ lines of the order of 20-40 mJy with a minimum line brightness of 28mJy. Scaling with the distance of NGC6334 and assuming a line width of 0.7 km/s (as observed in Tan et al. 2013) , we request a 25 mJy/beam sensitivity to allow the 5 sigma detection of N2D+ lines of prestellar cores within NGC6334 MDCs.
On the other hand, Hunter et al. (2014) observed I(N) in NGC 6334 with SMA and found for the main fragments (M>2Msun in ~2000 AU) a 13CS integrated intensity of 1 Jy/beam. Assuming the same line width as for N2D+, namely 0.7 km/s, we need to detect a 5 sigma sensitivity of 40mJy/beam to detect five massive protostars five times less massive that I(N).
Combining both estimations, we need a 13CS-N2D+ (Baseband-3) line rms of 25mJy (~0.89K) to detect and estimate linewidth/turbulence level for the complete evolutionary range of our sample.

We propose to observe 6 lines within three basebands and to keep one baseband for continuum at 214.5Ghz. The continuum baseband will be used to estimate masses for the detected protostellar or prestellar cores.
The estimated continuum sensitivity (sigma = 320?Jy/beam) for a 3-sigma detection is 0.96mJy/beam (34.2mK), which is the 215GHz continuum flux expected for a 0.3 Msun core at 1.7kpc (with kappa=0.01 cm2 g-1 and T=20K).
We expect minimum linewidths of ~0.7km/s for 13CS and N2D+ lines (Tan et al. 2013) and thus need a 13CS-N2D+ spectral window resolution of 0.158km/s.
We spectrally averaged outflows and infalls lines that we anticipate to be broader to save up datarate.

We propose to observe the 29 MDCs of NGC 6334 with ALMA. We aim to reach a 0.8" synthetized beam corresponding to 1500 AU at the 1.7kpc distance of NGC 6334. Previous interferometric studies of massive dense cores in Cygnus-X (Bontemps et al. 2010) or fragmentation in I(N) (Hunter et al. 2014) found that high-mass protostars in such cores (at a resolution of 1700 AU and 650 AU respectively) have deconvolved sizes on the order of 1000-2500 AU and mean separation of ~4000 AU.

TP observations are necessary to make sense of DCO+ and DCN line emissions, expected to arise from large-scale (up to 40") inflowing streams (see Fig.3-Right).
A second SG will investigate the complementary sample of 8 sources which are clustered at less than 30". We propose mosaics of 14, 23 and 14-pointings to spare redundant pointings.

We plan to assess the turbulence of the fragments using both 13CS and N2D+, 13CS being more suited for protostellar MDCs and N2D+ for starless MDCs. While 13 CS has been found to be an excellent tracer of high-mass Iprotostellar cores (Fechtenbaum et al. in prep.), it can be depleted in cold environment where N2D+ is enhanced and becomes a better tracer (Tan et al. 2013).
On one hand, Tan et al. (2013) uses ALMA Cycle 0 observations of prestellar dense cores embedded in IRDCS and detected N2D+ but not 13CS lines. Their intermediate-mass pre-stellar does display N2D+ lines of the order of 20-40 mJy with a minimum line brightness of 28mJy. On the other hand, Hunter et al. (2014) observed I(N) in NGC 6334 with SMA and found for the main fragments (M>2Msun in ~2000 AU) a 13CS integrated intensity of 1 Jy/beam. Assuming the same line width as for N2D+, namely 0.7 km/s, we need to detect a 5 sigma sensitivity of 40mJy/beam to detect five massive protostars five times less massive that I(N).
Combining both estimations, we need a 13CS-N2D+ (Baseband-3) line rms of 25mJy (~0.89K) to detect and estimate linewidth/turbulence level for the complete evolutionary range of our sample.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Despite all the recent efforts to characterize the earliest phases of high-mass star formation, the existence of high-mass pre-stellar cores is still debated. NGC 6334 is the closest most massive molecular complex of the Southern hemisphere forming high-mass stars. The Herschel/HOBYS program made a survey of NGC 6334 and an utter search for cloud fragments able to form high-mass stars. HOBYS revealed 29 cold, massive dense cores (MDCs) hosting either young high-mass protostars, massive pre-stellar cores, or both. We here propose to: -follow the fragmentation of these ~0.1 pc Herschel sources down to the ~2000 AU scale of protostars -seek CO outflows to distinguish between high-mass protostars and massive pre-stellar cores -compare the fragmentation level of protostellar and starless MDCs -measure the turbulence level of high-mass protostars and massive pre-stellar cores using 13CS and N2D+ lines, respectively -look for gas stream flowing from parsec-scale to 2000 AU protostars in DCO+ and DNC -conclude on the most likely scenario to form high-mass stars: either the local collapse of a turbulent massive pre-stellar core or the clump-scale gas accretion onto a low-mass protostar.
